item.title: Democrats Demand Guardrails as Government Shutdown Looms
item.description: Senate Democrats listed their conditions to allow a funding bill for the Department of Homeland Security to pass. If the bill stalls, the government could shut down at the Friday deadline.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Word of the Day: pertain
item.description: This word has appeared in 39 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: No Child Deserves to Die Like My Daughter
item.description: What was done to my daughter did not break me. It left me with a mother’s responsibility to ensure no child is left unheard.
item.dc:creator: Wesam Hamada

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by Shannon Lin/The New York Times. Photograph courtesy Wesam Hamada.

item.title: Trump’s Greenland Envoy: We Need ‘Total, Unfettered Access’
item.description: Trump’s special envoy to Greenland argues that the U.S. needs Greenland to defend it, American allies and American security.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Landry
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump amenaza a Irán con una ‘armada enorme’ e impone una serie de exigencias
item.description: Funcionarios estadounidenses y europeos afirman que han planteado tres exigencias a los iraníes, incluido el fin permanente de todo enriquecimiento de uranio.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: How His Duel With Trump Boosted Emmanuel Macron, France’s Embattled President
item.description: Dismissed as a lame duck, Emmanuel Macron has clawed back some influence after his defense of Greenland and Denmark. Will quieter domestic politics allow him to secure his legacy?
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

media:content.media:description: French President Emmanuel Macron meeting on Wednesday with Denmark’s Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen, right, and Greenland Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen.

item.title: Quote of the Day: All-Night Concerts Bring a War-Ravaged Nation Momentary Normalcy
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 29, 2026.

item.title: At World’s Busiest Port, China’s Unbalanced Economy Comes Into View
item.description: The shipping traffic and factories never stop in China’s port city of Ningbo, but the local housing market has crashed and nearby restaurants sit empty.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 29, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 29, 2026.

item.title: She Couldn’t Defend Herself, but He Wasn’t Charged With Rape
item.description: A decision in China not to charge a man who fathered children with a woman with a mental illness has set off a debate about consent and the state’s push for babies.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Driver Rams Car Into Headquarters of Chabad Hasidic Movemen
item.description: No one was injured when the motorist drove into a rear door of the building on Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. The man was arrested; the police are investigating the incident as a hate crime.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman and Brian Josephs

media:content.media:description: After a motorist rammed his car into a side entrance of the global headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitch Orthodox Jewish movement in Brooklyn, police officers swarmed the scene.

item.title: Trump and Schumer Move Toward Possible Deal to Avert a Shutdown
item.description: The president and the top Senate Democrat were discussing an agreement to split off homeland security funding from a broader spending package and negotiate new limits on immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse

media:content.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Another Top Kennedy Center Official Resigns
item.description: Kevin Couch, who was announced as senior vice president of artistic programming less than two weeks ago, is the latest to leave since President Trump took control of the center last year.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The exterior of The Kennedy Center this month.

item.title: Así fue como Trump supo que tenía un gran problema en Mineápolis
item.description: El presidente de EE. UU. suele fanfarronear en las crisis y negarse a retroceder. Mineápolis puso a prueba los límites de esa estrategia.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:description: Trump ha perfeccionado una táctica de supervivencia a lo largo de muchos años de enfrentarse a las críticas de la opinión pública.

item.title: U.K.’s Starmer Meets Xi Jinping in Beijing as Ties Warm
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain met with President Xi Jinping of China as he sought to promote business ties with the world’s second-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson

media:content.media:description: Chinese and British delegations participating in a bilateral meeting with President Xi Jinping and Prime Minister Keir Starmer in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 29, 2026
item.description: Kit Sheffield makes a mind-bending New York Times Crossword debut.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Shooting Aftermath Leaves Homeland Security Department in Turmoil
item.description: As officials point fingers in the wake of Alex Pretti’s death at the hands of federal agents, concerns grow about the agency’s future.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents clearing protesters from a hotel in Minneapolis on Sunday night.

item.title: The Journey of a Group of Cuban Deportees Stuck at Guantánamo
item.description: The tale illustrates how inefficient the ICE operation has been in the year since President Trump ordered the base to prepare for up to 30,000 “criminal aliens.”
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: An upper tier at Camp 6 detention center in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in 2019. It is a former prison for Al Qaeda suspects, which now houses dozens of Cuban men designated for deportation from the United States.

item.title: Dante de Blasio Was Among Those Arrested at Hilton Protest Against ICE
item.description: “I thought it was the right thing to do,” former Mayor Bill de Blasio’s son said. He was issued a summons after joining demonstrators in the lobby of the Hilton Garden Inn in TriBeCa.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

media:content.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Dante de Blasio, top right, holding a banner in the back of the group of protesters at the Hilton Garden Inn on Tuesday night.

item.title: Videos Show Alex Pretti in Confrontation With Agents 11 Days Before His Death
item.description: More than a week before federal agents killed Mr. Pretti, a Minneapolis nurse, different agents pushed him to the ground after he spit at them and broke a taillight on their S.U.V.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial to Alex Pretti, who was fatally shot by immigration agents on Saturday, at the site where he was killed in South Minneapolis.

item.title: Judge Orders Release of Minnesota Refugees Targeted in ICE Crackdown
item.description: A federal judge granted a temporary restraining order, which halts a Trump administration operation that has swept up at least 100 people so far.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan

media:content.media:description: Federal agents arrested a man after pursuing him on foot in Minneapolis earlier this month.

item.title: How Trump Is Weaponizing the Global System
item.description: How is Trump exploiting the liberal international system? Henry Farrell, an international relations scholar, explains on “The Ezra Klein Show.”
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: How Trump Is Trying to Recast American Power
item.description: What do American power and Facebook have in common? Henry Farrell, an international relations scholar, explains on “The Ezra Klein Show.”
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: The Man ICE Agents Were Seeking When They Killed Alex Pretti Remains at Large
item.description: Federal officials said agents were looking for an Ecuadorean named Jose Huerta-Chuma. Records show he faced allegations of domestic assault and had several traffic infractions.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:description: Gregory Bovino, right, and other immigration officials have cast their deportation campaign as a hunt for criminals.

item.title: Trump Administration Denies That Coercion Is at Heart of Minnesota ICE Surge
item.description: A federal judge weighing whether to block the immigration surge asked Justice Department lawyers to more fully explain the reasons for the operation.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents detaining a man outside his home on Tuesday in St. Paul, Minn., amid an immigration operation.

item.title: ICE Agents Blocked From Entering Ecuadorean Consulate in Minneapolis
item.description: Video footage obtained by The New York Times showed federal immigration agents trying to enter the Ecuadorean Consulate in Minneapolis on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Will Submit Monthly Budget to White House
item.description: Democrats sharply questioned the plan, including the role of Qatar in managing an account funded by the sale of Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley

media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations during a hearing to examine U.S. policy towards Venezuela.

item.title: N.Y.P.D. Searches Target Black and Latino Drivers, Lawsuit Says
item.description: The New York Civil Liberties Union accused the Police Department of discrimination in a federal lawsuit that calls for an end to the practice.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer

media:content.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Justin Cohen is one of the people on whose behalf the New York Civil Liberties Union is suing the New York Police Department. The organization is accusing the department of targeting Black and Latino drivers.

item.title: America at a Boiling Point: From ICE Protests to an Attack on Rep. Omar
item.description: An attack at a town hall in Minneapolis, amid a surge in threats against lawmakers, was the latest sign of the fraying of the nation’s political fabric.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Ilhan Omar after being sprayed with a foul-smelling liquid by an assailant at a town hall on Tuesday night in Minneapolis.

item.title: Homelessness Appears to Decline, Reversing a Yearslong Trend
item.description: The Trump administration has not yet released the count, which could complicate its plans for tough new policies.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle

media:content.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A homeless encampment in Chicago in March 2024. Local data collected by The New York Times showed that homelessness fell 60 percent in Chicago in the last year of the Biden administration.

item.title: Democrats Demand Unmasked Agents, New Limits to Fund D.H.S.
item.description: Ahead of a Friday shutdown deadline, Democrats laid out their conditions for funding the Department of Homeland Security, including new restrictions on immigration officers.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson

media:content.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the minority leader, presented Republicans with a specific proposal that Democrats said they would insist on in exchange for their votes.

item.title: How Trump Is Transforming the Oval Office
item.description: Our White House photographer Doug Mills breaks down how the Oval Office has been transformed in the first year of President Trump’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Doug Mills, Rebecca Suner, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Laura Salaberry, Junho Lee and Mika Gröndahl

item.title: Judge Questions Trump Administration’s Push to Halt Congestion Pricing
item.description: As a legal battle continues over the fate of New York City’s toll program, a judge appeared skeptical of the federal government’s arguments, but did not issue a ruling.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen and Winnie Hu

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Congestion pricing went into effect last January for drivers entering Manhattan below 60th Street.

item.title: Is K-pop’s Cute Era Over?
item.description: Our critic Jon Caramanica on how Illit’s new sonic direction reflects this current moment in K-pop.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Arjun Srivatsa and Joe Coscarelli

item.title: Victim in School Sex Abuse Case Wins $30 Million Jury Award
item.description: The man, now 44, said that a teacher in Newark repeatedly sexually abused him in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

media:content.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ann Street School in Newark, where a 44-year-old man said he was abused as a child by an after-school teacher in the 1990s.

item.title: Angella Ferguson, a Leader in Sickle Cell Anemia Research, Dies at 100
item.description: A Black female doctor when that was rare, she developed a diagnostic test for the disease that is still a standard tool, as well as treatment guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Judge Scolds Bondi for Publishing Photos of Protesters on Social Media
item.description: “This conduct is not something that the court condones,” Judge Dulce J. Foster said during a hearing in a Minneapolis federal court.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Lauren McCarthy

media:content.media:description: Federal agents arresting a protester in Minneapolis this month.

item.title: Judge in Minnesota Says ICE Has Violated Nearly 100 Court Orders
item.description: A federal judge said ICE had disobeyed more judicial directives this month than “some federal agencies have violated in their entire existence.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:description: Federal agents arrested and carried a protester in south Minneapolis earlier this month.

item.title: Un avión con políticos colombianos se estrella en una zona disputada por un grupo rebelde
item.description: En el avión viajaban 15 personas, incluyendo dos políticos locales, Diógenes Quintero y Carlos Salcedo, que estaban postulados como candidatos al Congreso en las próximas elecciones nacionales.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak

media:content.media:description: El avión que se estrelló era un Beechcraft 1900, similar a este.

item.title: Geoff Mason, Sports Producer Thrust Into Covering Terrorism, Dies at 85
item.description: He played a critical role in ABC Sports’s reporting on the attack by a Palestinian group at the 1972 Summer Games in Munich that left 11 Israeli team members dead.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:credit: American Broadcasting Companies, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Geoffrey Mason, with ABC Sports, at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Alberta, Canada. He won 24 Emmy Awards for producing coverage of sports events.

item.title: Sergey Brin Spends $20 Million on California Political Effort Amid Wealth Tax Debate
item.description: Sergey Brin donated $20 million to a new political drive aimed at solving California’s housing crisis, spurring other billionaires to pitch in. Their efforts may also help ward off a wealth tax.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall and Theodore Schleifer

media:content.media:description: Sergey Brin’s group says it is trying to solve problems and help middle-class workers pay for housing in a state where the median home price has surpassed $850,000.

item.title: 5 Key Takeaways from Josh Shapiro’s Memoir ‘Where We Keep the Light’
item.description: Politically pointed and heavy on his Jewish faith, the book already has Democrats talking.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania

item.title: Why the NORAD Cold War Pact Between the U.S. and Canada Is News
item.description: The State Department clarified comments made by the U.S. Ambassador to Canada that NORAD would be “altered” if that country did not purchase American F-35 jets.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies

media:content.media:description: Canada began a review of its agreement to buy F-35 fighter jets from the United States last year. The United States still wants Canada to use those jets for the common defense of North American airspace.

item.title: Agents Who Shot Alex Pretti Are Put on Leave
item.description: Also, the F.B.I. searched a Georgia election center. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:description: A screen grab from a bystander video shows Alex Pretti on the ground before federal agents shot and killed him.

item.title: These Machines Melt Snow Off of NYC Streets in Seconds
item.description: Large tubs have been placed around New York City to melt snow after the city received about 12 inches over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Fetherston, Heather Khalifa and Christopher Maag

item.title: Mamdani Blames Rivals for Leaving New York With a ‘Poisoned’ Budget
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said the only way to close a more than $12 billion budget gap was to raise taxes on the wealthy and corporations.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, joined by his budget director, Sherif Soliman, left, and Deputy Mayor Dean Fuleihan, warned of a huge budget gap.

item.title: Who’s Supposed to Clear the Snow From New York City’s Street Corners?
item.description: Three days after the city’s biggest snowstorm in years, many New Yorkers are still scaling mounds of snow and ice. Cleaning it up is a shared responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Nate Schweber

media:content.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: While New York City’s streets have been cleared since a major snowstorm on Sunday, cold temperatures have kept the remaining snow from melting, leaving it piled on sidewalks.

item.title: Man Sentenced to 15 Years for Role in Plot to Kill Iranian Dissident
item.description: Carlisle Rivera became the third person to be sentenced for playing a role in trying to kill Masih Alinejad, an activist and a critic of the Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan

media:content.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Masih Alinejad leaves Federal District Court in Manhattan after testifying in the trial of two men charged with plotting to assassinate her.

item.title: ‘No Win’ for Minneapolis Police Caught Between Trump and City Residents
item.description: With the Trump administration accusing local police of dereliction and some in the community feeling unprotected, outnumbered Minneapolis officers find themselves facing difficult choices.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault and Chelsia Rose Marcius

media:content.media:description: A Minneapolis police officer stands on duty at an intersection near the spot where Renee Good was shot and killed earlier this month.

item.title: F.B.I. Search in Georgia Tied to Criminal Inquiry Over 2020 Election
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
